thread.title: N.Y. boy, 10, dies after being trapped under 2 feet of snow
thread.title_full: N.Y. boy, 10, dies after being trapped under 2 feet of snow

author: ELIZABETH ELIZALDE
title: N.Y. boy, 10, dies after being trapped under 2 feet of snow
text:
10-year-old New York boy dies after being trapped under 2 feet of snow N.Y. boy, 10, dies after being trapped under 2 feet of snow NEW YORK DAILY NEWS   4:41 PM 
A 10-year-old boy in upstate New York died after being trapped for several minutes under a pile of snow Wednesday, officials and his family said. 
Benjamin Wasik was digging a tunnel in the snow at a home on Aiken Road in Pendleton when snow collapsed on him around 3:40 p.m., the Niagara County Sherriff's Office said. 
“It was a snow day, and he was doing what kids do,” Benjamin’s aunt, Diane Wasik Reed, 50, of Pendleton, told the Daily News Thursday. “He was the most gentle, most quietest and beautiful boy you would ever come across.” 
Benjamin, who loved "Star Wars" and the outdoors, was outside with his father, David Wasik, at his grandparent’s upstate farm where he was playing in the snow, and his dad was trying to clean the residence’s driveway, she said. 
Man found dead in Brooklyn snow bank wanted to marry girlfriend 
“Five minutes later, he turns around, and didn’t see Ben,” Wasik Reed said. 
The father started calling for his son and even searched the home, but there was still no sign of Benjamin. 
David and his wife Melissa Wasik eventually found their son 10 minutes later and they performed CPR to try to revive him. Wasik Reed said about 2 feet of snow had fallen on the boy. Benjamin Wasik, 10, was found dead after snow collapsed on him while he was digging a tunnel in a pile of snow in Pendleton, N.Y. (Family Handout) 
Benjamin was taken to Millard Fillmore Suburban Hospital where he was pronounced dead. His death has been ruled accidental and caused by asphyxiation, officials said. 
Wasik Reed and her husband arrived at the hospital after Benjamin’s parents received the devastating news. Doctors “tried and tried, above and beyond,” to save her nephew, she said. 
The incident is being investigated by the sheriff's office Criminal Investigation Bureau. 
The Starpoint School District — where Benjamin was a fourth-grader at Regan Intermediate School — released a statement offering its condolences to the Wasik family and that crisis counseling was set up for students and faculty members. 
Funeral services for Benjamin will be held this Sunday in Lockport, his aunt said. Tags:
